title: Gold Climbs as Rising Geopolitical and Trade Tensions Aid Havens
content: Gold rose — after falling by 2% last week — as an increase in geopolitical and trade tensions revived demand for haven assets.

title: Air India CEO on Growth Outlook
content: Campbell Wilson, CEO and Managing Director of Air India, discusses his outlook for business and growth strategy for the airline. He speaks with Guy Johnson on "Bloomberg: The China Show" from the sidelines of the IATA Annual General Meeting & World Air Transport Summit in New Delhi.  (Source: Bloomberg)

title: A $73 Billion Short Book Is Putting Pressure on Indian Rupee
content: The Indian rupee is emerging Asia’s worst performer this quarter and may continue to lag peers as the central bank aims to avert a depletion in its foreign-exchange reserves, according to analysts.

title: Gallarati: Not a Bad Time for OPEC+ to Increase Production
content: Oil has been trading lower ahead of an OPEC+ meeting on output which is expected to lead to another supply hike. Livia Gallarati, Global Crude Lead at Energy Aspects told Bloomberg's Horizons Middle East and Africa anchor Joumanna Bercetche that the timing of the supply hike may be beneficial. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Stocks Drop, Gold Rises as Trade Tensions Flare Up: Markets Wrap
content: Asian shares dropped along with US stock-index futures as trade tensions worsened, prompting investors to hold back on taking risky bets. Gold rose on demand for haven assets.

title: Revved-Up Polish Assets at Risk With Nationalist Winning Ballot
content: Investors in Polish stocks and bonds — among the world’s stand-out performers of 2025 — are on edge as a nationalist won the presidential election, dealing a blow to the pro-European government.

title: IATA's Willie Walsh on How Tariffs May Impact Aviation
content: Bloomberg's Guy Johnson speaks to Willie Walsh of the International Air Transport Association. Walsh was speaking on the sidelines of IATA's annual meeting where the global aviation industry convenes to discuss issues affecting the sector. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Owner of Leela Luxury Hotels Declines on Trading Debut in Mumbai
content: The operator of the Leela luxury hotels fell on its Mumbai trading debut, a lackluster start to India’s second-largest initial public offering this year.

title: Hong Kong’s 2025 Growth Outlook Cut by AMRO on Trade Uncertainty
content: Hong Kong’s growth outlook was cut by a regional organization, which urged the city to diversify its economy and trading partners to counter growing protectionism.

title: ECB Set for Last Easy Rate Cut as Trade Fuels Inflation Discord
content: The European Central Bank is about to lower interest rates for the final time before an increasingly complicated inflation outlook risks bringing internal divisions to the fore.

title: Airline Industry Scales Back Profit Outlook Amid Trade Tensions
content: The global airline industry stands to earn a collective $36 billion this year, a downward revision from the most recent prediction issued in December amid growing trade tensions and a drop in consumer confidence, the leading aviation association said.

title: Emirates' Clark on Tariff Impact, Supply Chains, Boeing
content: Emirates President Tim Clark discusses air travel demand and supply chains amid the uncertainty around tariffs. He also shares his views on the carrier's relationship with Boeing and passenger numbers to the US. Clark speaks with Bloomberg’s Guy Johnson on the sidelines of the IATA Annual General Meeting & World Air Transport Summit in New Delhi.  (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Triata Capital: Bullish on PDD
content: Sean Ho, Founder & CIO at Triata Capital, discusses why he sees further upside for PDD despite risks from US-China tensions. The US-listed Chinese e-commerce firm was Ho's investment pick at this year's Sohn Hong Kong Investment Leaders Conference. He speaks with Yvonne Man and Annabelle Droulers on "Bloomberg The China Show."  (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Bloomberg: The Asia Trade 6/2/25
content: "Bloomberg: The Asia Trade" brings you everything you need to know to get ahead as the trading day begins in Asia. Bloomberg TV is live from Seoul and Sydney with Shery Ahn and Haidi Stroud-Watts, getting insight and analysis from newsmakers and industry leaders on the biggest stories shaping global markets. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: HK Express CEO on Business Outlook
content: Jeanette Mao, CEO at HK Express, discusses her plans to keep the low-cost carrier's edge after becoming the fastest growing airline in 2024. She speaks with Guy Johnson on "Bloomberg: The China Show" from the sidelines of the IATA Annual General Meeting & World Air Transport Summit in New Delhi.  (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Philippines Orders AirAsia MOVE Shutdown on Excessive Pricing
content: The Philippines has ordered AirAsia’s digital platform to stop selling airline tickets in the country following complaints it charged illegally high fares.

title: Philippines Eyes India, Thailand Rice to Cut Vietnam Reliance
content: The Philippines, the world’s top rice importer, plans to look beyond its dominant supplier, Vietnam, to ensure steady supplies and competitive prices at home.

title: Carry Trades Roar Back as Emerging Market Currencies Gain
content: Emerging market carry trades are taking off again, as currency volatility subsides amid signs President Donald Trump’s aggressive tariffs may not get fully enacted.

title: Morgan Stanley Sees Three More OPEC+ Hikes Driving Brent Lower
content: OPEC+ is set to continue returning production for another three months, which will help drive oil prices lower, according to Morgan Stanley.

title: New World’s Distress Worsens After Shock Delay on Bond Interest
content: Hong Kong developer New World Development Co. is sliding deeper into distress after jolting investors by delaying interest payments on some bonds, marking the latest flashpoint in a years-long crisis in China’s property market.

title: Hedge Funds Slash Bullish Yen Bets as Asset Managers Stand Firm
content: Leveraged funds reduced their bullish yen bets even as asset managers turned more positive, underscoring uncertainty over the Japanese currency’s outlook.

title: Iron Ore Hits One-Month Low on Trump’s Plan to Hike Steel Levies
content: Iron ore fell to its lowest level since early May alongside equity markets after President Donald Trump said he would double tariffs on steel and aluminum to help protect American workers.

title: China’s Coal Industry Has a Big, Dirty Secret
content: Largely unnoticed, an obscure corner of the trade has reached gargantuan proportions.

title: Oil Gains as Geopolitical Concerns Rise, OPEC+ Boosts Supply
content: Oil advanced after geopolitical and trade risk increased over the weekend, and as OPEC+ hiked production less than some had feared.

title: Chinese Stocks Score Over Indian Peers on Tally of Analyst Bets
content: Investors have more to gain from buying Chinese shares than those in India, according to a tally of analysts’ estimates.

title: Chinese Shares Fall in Hong Kong on New Trade Frictions With US
content: Chinese shares traded in Hong Kong fell on Monday, as heightened US-China trade tensions jolted market sentiment.

title: India’s Growth Surprise to Favor Infrastructure and Consumer Stocks
content: Before the trading day starts we bring you a digest of the key news and events that are likely to move markets. Today we look at:

title: TriVista Capital CEO: Long on Santen Pharmaceutical
content: Masaki Gotoh, CEO and CIO at TriVista Capital, discusses his investment strategy in Japan and why he chose to go long on ophthalmology firm Santen Pharmaceutical at the Sohn Hong Kong Investment Leaders Conference. He speaks with Shery Ahn and Haidi Stroud-Watts on "Bloomberg: The Asia Trade". (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Good Prospects for Chinese Companies to Flourish, HSBC Says
content: HSBC's Herald van der Linde shares his outlook for Asian and Chinese equities on Bloomberg Television. He says "there is good prospects for these companies to flourish." For the Chinese stock market in particular, he advises looking at banks as well as "companies that will become global leaders in their respective industries," such as EVs and industrial robotics. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: AmCham President Says China Isn’t Blocking Rare Earths Exports
content: China has been slowly loosening the grip on its exports of rare earths over the past week, according to a lobby group for American businesses, after top US officials complained it hadn’t been removing barriers as promised.

title: At Least 21 Palestinians Killed Heading to Gaza Aid Hub, Hospital Says
content: RAFAH, Gaza Strip (AP) — At least 31 people were killed and over 170 were wounded Sunday as large crowds were on their way to receive food in the Gaza Strip, health officials and witnesses said. Witnesses said Israeli forces fired toward the crowds just before dawn around a kilometer (about 1,100 yards) from an aid site run by an Israeli-backed foundation.

title: South Africa’s Black Empowerment Laws and the Long Shadow of Apartheid
content: During the eras of colonialism and apartheid, Black South Africans were subjugated, denied a decent education, and excluded from the mainstream economy. Severe racial disparities endure to this day, more than three decades after the end of White-minority rule. South Africa ranks as one of the world’s most unequal countries, according to analysis by the World Inequality Lab.

title: Revved-Up Polish Assets at Risk With Nationalist Winning Ballot
content: Investors in Polish stocks and bonds — among the world’s stand-out performers of 2025 — are on edge as a nationalist won the presidential election, dealing a blow to the pro-European government.

title: Taiwan Warns of Rise in Chinese Military Activity Around Region
content: Taiwan said China escalated military pressure around the region in May, deploying dozens of warships and government vessels daily in what it described as an extreme pressure campaign.

title: Pro-Trump Nationalist Wins Poland’s Presidential Election
content: A nationalist candidate backed by Donald Trump won Poland’s presidential election, defeating the centrist mayor of Warsaw in a blow to the country’s pro-European Union government.

title: China Accuses US of Violating Trade Deal, Vows Firm Response
content: China accused the US of violating their recent trade deal and vowed to take measures to defend its interests, dimming the prospect of an immediate leadership call that Donald Trump wants to have to further bilateral talks.

title: Japan’s Akazawa Reportedly Mulls Return to US This Week
content: Japan’s top trade negotiator Ryosei Akazawa is considering returning to the US for another round of trade negotiations this week as expectations mount for a deal as early as this month.

title: Chile Presidential Polls Show Matthei With Slight Lead Over Kast
content: Chile center-right presidential candidate Evelyn Matthei held a small lead over more conservative contender Jose Antonio Kast atop two polls published on Sunday, reflecting an open race for the nation’s top job.

title: Southeast Asia Joins Europe’s Calls to Defend Subsea Cables
content: Defense officials from Europe and Southeast Asia called for stronger collaboration to protect the global network of subsea cables as concerns grow over threats to this vital infrastructure.

title: Hegseth Wins Praise But Asia Still Has Strong Doubts About Trump
content: After US military allies in Europe were torched by Vice President JD Vance in March over military spending, free speech and the war in Ukraine, America’s partners in Asia warily awaited Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth’s arrival at a security conference in Singapore.

title: South Korea’s Election Frontrunner Still Leaves Many Unconvinced
content: Lee Jae-myung is still the frontrunner in South Korea’s presidential race, but what once looked like a landslide victory has turned into a much closer contest.

title: US Calls on Australia to Boost Defense Spending to 3.5% of GDP
content: US Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth has asked Australia to dramatically raise its military spending to 3.5% of gross domestic product “as soon as possible,” according to an official readout of his meeting with Australia’s Defence Minister Richard Marles.

title: South Korea Crypto Industry to Gain No Matter Who Wins Election
content: No matter who clinches South Korea’s presidential election this week, one outcome is certain: the country’s crypto industry is poised to win.

title: UK to Build More Attack Submarines in ‘Message to Moscow’
content: The UK intends to send a “message to Moscow” with plans to expand its fleet of attack submarines and invest in its nuclear deterrent as part of a new defense strategy to head off the threat posed by Russia.

title: Sudan’s Army-Backed Prime Minister Poised to Form New Government
content: Sudan’s army-appointed Prime Minister Kamil Idris dissolved the government in preparation to form a new cabinet, almost two weeks after he was announced as the war-torn country’s first premier in more than three years.

title: Chile’s Boric Vows to Rely Less on Israel, Citing Gaza Violence
content: Chile President Gabriel Boric vowed to diversify his nation’s defense ties to depend less on Israel, issuing a scathing rebuke over violence in Gaza during his annual State of the Nation address on Sunday.

title: Pro-EU Mayor Takes Slim Lead in Poland Vote, Exit Polls Show
content: The centrist mayor of Warsaw took a slim lead in Poland’s presidential election over a nationalist candidate backed by Donald Trump, giving a boost to the country’s pro-European Union government, exit polls show.

title: Graham Aims for Tough New Russia Sanctions Ahead of G-7 Summit
content: Republican Senator Lindsey Graham, a close ally of President Donald Trump, said he aims to have new sanctions imposed on Russia before the Group of Seven summit in late June.

title: Carney Picks Canadian Pension Executive as Next Chief of Staff
content: Prime Minister Mark Carney is hiring an executive from one of Canada’s top pension fund managers to be his chief of staff.

title: Trump Pulls Nomination of Musk Ally Isaacman to Lead NASA
content: President Donald Trump said he would name a new nominee for NASA administrator, just days before billionaire Jared Isaacman, the current pick and a close ally of Elon Musk, was to face his planned Senate confirmation vote.

title: Slovak Leader Rules Out Support for Kazimir’s Return as Governor
content: Prime Minister Robert Fico will not support the reappointment of Peter Kazimir as head of Slovakia’s central bank, the Slovak leader said on Sunday.

title: UK Joins US, France in Backing Morocco Plan for West Sahara
content: The UK backed Morocco’s plan to administer the disputed territory of Western Sahara, in a historic shift mirroring moves by France and the US.

title: Bessent Says US Will Never Default as Congress Faces Endgame
content: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said the US “is never going to default” as the deadline for increasing the federal debt ceiling gets closer.

title: Musk Denies Ketamine Use Following New York Times Report
content: Billionaire Elon Musk said that he is not using the drug ketamine, disputing a report by the New York Times that alleged extensive use of that and other drugs.

title: Germany Plans Corporate Tax Breaks to Spur Investment, DPA Says
content: German Finance Minister Lars Klingbeil is planning a number of tax breaks for companies aimed at spurring investment and lifting the economy out of its long bout of stagnation, according to Deutsche Presse-Agentur.

title: UK Shifts War Footing To ‘Always-On’ Munitions Production
content: The UK will create an “always on” munitions production capacity to allow it to scale-up its defense industry when needed, as it increasingly shifts to a war footing with Russia’s assault on Ukraine showing little sign of ending.

title: Hegseth Reassures Asia Allies Unsettled by Trump: Balance of Power
content: Welcome to a special edition of Balance of Power, focusing on the IISS Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore. Each weekday we bring you the latest in global politics. If you haven’t yet, sign up here.

title: Trump’s Steel Tariffs ‘Economic Self Harm,’ Australian PM Says
content: Donald Trump’s decision to double steel tariffs on imports was “inappropriate” but it won’t impact Australia any more than it would other countries, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said.

title: Hungary’s Top Court Strikes Down Police Ban on LGBTQ Gathering
content: Hungary’s top court struck down a police ban of a pro-LGBTQ gathering in Budapest, in a test of Prime Minister Viktor Orban’s escalating culture war before elections next year.

title: Bangladesh Charges Ex-PM Hasina With Crimes Against Humanity
content: Bangladeshi prosecutors officially charged former prime minister Sheikh Hasina and two senior officials with crimes against humanity for their alleged roles in violent crackdowns during the 2024 student-led uprising.

title: Poland Swings Rightward With Nationalist Win
content: Welcome to the Brussels Edition, Bloomberg’s daily briefing on what matters most in the heart of the European Union.A nationalist candidate backed by President Donald Trump won Poland’s presidential election, defeating the centrist mayor of Warsaw in a blow to the the country’s current government. Karol Nawrocki, a historian and former boxer who has made clear his core Catholic values while railing against migration and the EU’s efforts to fight climate change, took 51% of the vote. Nawrocki’s v

Ukraine staged a dramatic series of strikes across Russia, deploying drones hidden in trucks deep inside the country to hit strategic airfields.

title: Nintendo Has a Shrewd Plan for Selling the Switch 2 in Japan
content: Nintendo Co. is making an unusual move with its Switch 2 distribution in Japan: It’s setting wholesale prices so retailers can earn more from each sale.

content: Defense officials from Europe and Southeast Asia called for stronger collaboration to protect the global network of subsea cables as concerns grow over threats to this vital infrastructure.

title: Samsung Nears Wide-Ranging Deal With Perplexity for AI Features
content: Samsung Electronics Co. is nearing a wide-ranging deal to invest in Perplexity AI Inc. and put search technology from the artificial intelligence startup at the forefront of the South Korean company’s devices.

title: Apple Developer Event Will Show It’s Still Far From Being an AI Leader
content: Apple, a year after debuting its AI platform, will do little at WWDC to show it’s catching up to leaders like OpenAI and Google. Also: The latest macOS gets its new California theme; a look at why the company is moving to an iOS 26 and macOS 26 naming system; and details on Apple’s dedicated gaming app.

title: Swedish Bankruptcy Rate Edges Higher in May Amid Consumer Gloom
content: The number of bankruptcies in Sweden continues to tick higher as the uncertainty surrounding tariffs weighs on consumers’ willingness to spend.

title: ECB Set for Last Easy Rate Cut as Trade Fuels Inflation Discord
content: The European Central Bank is about to lower interest rates for the final time before an increasingly complicated inflation outlook risks bringing internal divisions to the fore.

title: Japan to Set Up Minister-Level Meeting to Address Rice Supplies
content: Japan will set up a minister-level meeting as early as this week to address the supply of rice, Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba said in parliament on Monday, as the government seeks to stabilize the price of the nation’s staple grain and quell public anger ahead of a summer election.

title: BOK’s Rhee Says US-China Trade Talks Important for Asia
content: Bank of Korea Governor Rhee Chang-yong said the outcome of trade negotiations between the US and China will have an impact on all of Asia’s economies, highlighting their significance beyond the bilateral level.

title: China Accuses US of Violating Trade Deal, Vows Firm Response
content: China accused the US of violating their recent trade deal and vowed to take measures to defend its interests, dimming the prospect of an immediate leadership call that Donald Trump wants to have to further bilateral talks.

title: Japan’s Akazawa Reportedly Mulls Return to US This Week
content: Japan’s top trade negotiator Ryosei Akazawa is considering returning to the US for another round of trade negotiations this week as expectations mount for a deal as early as this month.

title: Trade War Hits Asia Factories as Exports, Production Slide
content: Manufacturing activity across several Asian nations weakened in May as US tariffs and trade uncertainty eroded demand.

title: Fed’s Waller Outlines Path to Rate Cuts Later This Year
content: Federal Reserve Governor Christopher Waller said he continues to see a path to interest-rate cuts later this year amid his expectations that tariffs will boost unemployment and temporarily increase inflation.

title: Stephen Roach Now Says It’s Too Early to Declare Hong Kong Over
content: Stephen Roach is revising his declaration that Hong Kong is finished.

title: Japan’s Firms Raised Capital Spending Ahead of US Tariffs
content: Japanese businesses increased capital investment at a faster pace in the first quarter of this year just as the Trump administration touted the coming tariff campaign that kicked off in March.

title: South Korea’s Election Frontrunner Still Leaves Many Unconvinced
content: Lee Jae-myung is still the frontrunner in South Korea’s presidential race, but what once looked like a landslide victory has turned into a much closer contest.

title: Pro-EU Mayor Takes Slim Lead in Poland Vote, Exit Polls Show
content: The centrist mayor of Warsaw took a slim lead in Poland’s presidential election over a nationalist candidate backed by Donald Trump, giving a boost to the country’s pro-European Union government, exit polls show.

title: Summers, Bernanke Recall Fischer as Brilliant Economic Scholar
content: Stanley Fischer was remembered Sunday as a mentor to economic luminaries around the world.

title: Stanley Fischer, Who Spread Macroeconomic Gospel, Dies at 81
content: Stanley Fischer, a professor and practitioner of macroeconomics who helped guide central banks in two countries, Israel and the US, and mentored a younger generation of economic decision-makers, has died. He was 81.

title: Trump’s Steel Tariffs ‘Economic Self Harm,’ Australian PM Says
content: Donald Trump’s decision to double steel tariffs on imports was “inappropriate” but it won’t impact Australia any more than it would other countries, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said.

title: China Home Sales Slump Drags On as Deflation Eats Into Incomes
content: China’s residential property sales continued to fall on in May, signaling the real estate slump is still weighing on an economy that’s under pressure from deflation and trade tensions.

title: US Job Growth Is Seen Moderating on Shifting Trade Policy
content: The pace of US hiring probably slowed in May, with employers focusing on containing costs as households become a bit more guarded and businesses reconsidered investment plans against a backdrop of shifting trade policy.

title: South Korea’s Exports Drop on Tariff and Political Risks
content: South Korea’s exports contracted in May, underscoring growing challenges for the trade-reliant economy as global demand weakens and uncertainties deepen over Donald Trump’s sweeping tariff push.

title: BOE’s Breeden Believes UK Labor Market Loosening: Sunday Times
content: Bank of England’s Sarah Breeden believes the UK labor market is loosening, while she sees “waves of disinflation” continuing, according to an interview the central bank deputy governor for financial stability gave to Sunday Times.

title: Confidence Among UK Directors Rebounds to Pre-Budget High
content: UK business confidence has recovered to levels last seen before Labour’s budget in October as investment intentions pick up but lingering fears of a global downturn continue to weigh on sentiment, according to the Institute of Directors.

title: Thousands Rally in Bulgaria to Protest Plan for Euro Adoption
content: Thousands of people gathered in dozens of cities across Bulgaria to protest against the adoption of the euro as authorities prepare to switch to the European Union’s single currency early next year.

title: Russian Assets Deserve Closer Look, German Official Tells FAS
content: The European Union should revisit the question of how hundreds of billions of euros in frozen Russian assets can be used to finance Ukraine, a top German official said.

title: Stablecoin Regulation Could Shakeup US Financial System
content: The Trump administration touts deregulation as a source of economic growth — the thinking is that removing what it sees as shackles on business will promote it. But sometimes it takes regulation to do that.

title: Thailand’s $115 Billion Budget Clears First Parliamentary Hurdle
content: Thailand’s lower house of parliament backed a 3.78 trillion baht ($115 billion) annual budget as Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra’s multi-party coalition buried differences to support the spending plan.

title: Charting the Global Economy: US GDP Falls on Larger Trade Hit
content: The US economy contracted slightly to start the year, largely reflecting a bigger tariff-related trade hit but also a larger downshift in household spending growth than first estimated.

title: How Do We Define a Currency?
content: A surprisingly difficult question.

title: ECB Officials Ready to Keep Working With Convicted Colleague
content: European Central Bank policymakers are prepared to keep working with their colleague Peter Kazimir despite his conviction for bribery this week, according to people familiar with their thinking.

title: Owner of Leela Luxury Hotels Declines on Trading Debut in Mumbai
content: The operator of the Leela luxury hotels fell on its Mumbai trading debut, a lackluster start to India’s second-largest initial public offering this year.

title: TDB Warns Losses on African Development Banks Set Dangerous Precedent
content: Forcing African development lenders to take losses in sovereign debt restructurings would set a dangerous precedent and increase the cost of financing on the continent, TDB Managing Director Admassu Tadesse cautioned.

title: Philippines Eyes India, Thailand Rice to Cut Vietnam Reliance
content: The Philippines, the world’s top rice importer, plans to look beyond its dominant supplier, Vietnam, to ensure steady supplies and competitive prices at home.

title: New World’s Distress Worsens After Shock Delay on Bond Interest
content: Hong Kong developer New World Development Co. is sliding deeper into distress after jolting investors by delaying interest payments on some bonds, marking the latest flashpoint in a years-long crisis in China’s property market.

title: BYD Faces Growing Backlash Over EV Price War as May Sales Jump
content: BYD Co. shares continued their plunge despite monthly sales climbing to the highest this year, as the steep discounts the industry uses to entice buyers draw scrutiny from Beijing.

title: Soul Patts, Brickworks Join After Decades of Cross-Ownership
content: Australian investment firm Washington H. Soul Pattinson and Co. and Brickworks Ltd. agreed to combine, finally simplifying a cross-shareholding between the two businesses that stretches back almost 60 years.

title: Immunotherapy Drugs Show Major Progress in Early-Stage Cancer
content: Drugs that boost the body’s immune system to fight disease are showing promise in treating a variety of cancers in earlier stages, a development primed to expand their use and transform care for stubborn diseases like gastric and colon cancer.

title: Coach’s Hit Handbag Shows How Less-Expensive Luxury Is Gaining Ground
content: Ultra-luxury is losing its luster — and mid-tier competitors are capitalizing.

title: Emirates Will Keep A380 Flying Until End of Next Decade
content: Emirates plans to keep its giant fleet of Airbus SE A380 double-deckers in operation until the end of next decade, as the world’s largest international airline seeks to extend the lifespan of an aircraft that helped lay the foundation for its dominance on global routes.

title: Airline Industry Benefiting From Lower Oil Price, IATA Head Says
content: The global aviation industry is benefiting from lower oil prices because they’re bringing down the cost of kerosene, the head of the IATA industry association said.

title: Boeing Says New Model to Replace 737 Max Not a Priority: FT
content: Launching a new aircraft to replace the best-selling Boeing 737 Max isn’t an immediate priority, the aircraft manufacturer’s Chief Executive Officer Kelly Ortberg told the Financial Times in an interview.

title: Korea’s Presidential Front-Runner Backs Nuclear Power — for Now
content: South Korea’s presidential front-runner Lee Jae-myung has pledged to keep nuclear power “for the time being,” but plans a long-term shift to renewables if elected June 3 — a stance that could undermine the nation’s atomic energy expansion plans at home and abroad.

title: Meyer Burger to Delay Results as Two Units File for Insolvency
content: Struggling solar-module manufacturer Meyer Burger Technology AG requested an extension of the deadline to present its 2024 financial results after its German units filed for insolvency proceedings.

title: Moderna Wins Narrower US Approval for New Covid Vaccine
content: Moderna Inc. gained US approval for a new Covid vaccine for a narrower group of people, in the latest sign that regulators are restricting access to immunizations under the leadership of Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr.

title: Adani Group Outlines Transport Network in Rebuild of Mumbai Slum

title: A Deep Dive Into The Leading Investors In Unicorns Minted Since 2023

title: Looking Back 10 Years, Seed Investors Envisioned A Different Future Unfolding

title: Global Venture Funding Slowed In April, Despite Strong AI Showing
content: Global venture funding totaled $23 billion in April 2025, flat year over year and down significantly month over month from $68 billion invested in March, Crunchbase data shows.

title: Most-Active Startup Investors Spent More In Q1
content: The busiest venture backers upped their game in the recently ended first quarter. Among the 14 most-active post-seed investors, a majority backed more deals in Q1 2025 than they did a year ago.

title: Europe’s VC Funding Stayed Flat In Q1, Even As Healthcare Added A Third
content: Europe’s venture funding plateaued at $12.6 billion in Q1 2025 — flat quarter over quarter and year over year, Crunchbase data shows. Without the sort of outsized AI funding rounds seen in North America in the first quarter, the continent’s share of global funding also fell.

title: Latin America Startup Funding Fell Sequentially In Q1
content: Latin America startup investment declined sequentially in the first quarter of this year, driven by a drop in later-stage dealmaking. Even so, funding was above the depressed levels seen a year ago, and early-stage dealmaking showed signs of strength.

title: SignalFire Closes On $1B To Invest In Applied AI

title: North America Startup Investment Spiked In Q1 Due To OpenAI, But Seed And Early Stage Fell
